I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I engaged with transatlantic literature and 18th - 19th c authors.

Through a thoughtful and diverse selection of readings, we learned of various histories of race and gender in the Black Atlantic. Readings covered feminist literature, colonialism, consumerism in the 18th/19th century, contemporary scholarship, slave narratives, and more. Despite the wide range of readings, the class was well organized and intentional in how readings were presented and paired with each other. We were able to form many complex conversations together about each of these themes/areas as a small group.

I learned so much about the literature of the long 18th century and read many novels I had no prior experience with (e.g. Oroonoko, The Woman of Colour, etc.). I especially appreciated our unit on indigenous feminism and early European feminism. Even though I am fairly involved with the present-day feminist movement, our readings showed me that there is still so much gender history I have yet to learn. I also gained more knowledge about the transatlantic slave trade and the influence of the slave trade on modern Black art and research.
I learned how to incorporate secondary sources into my essays; how to consider the entire context of quotes; how to analyze plays, short stories, poems, and novels.
Analysis of long 18th-century transatlantic history and literature, with a focus on (as the title implies) discussion of race and gender, and the works of Black, indigenous, and female authors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course had a really great syllabus and supplementary readings.

Some strengths include the reading list, Prof. Campbell and they way she leads discussion, and the feedback you get from Prof. Campbell (and other students) throughout the course. Though the language in some of the literature is difficult to read, the themes are interesting and important. I sometimes felt burdened by the amount of reading, especially in this semester of online classes, but I always got something out of each reading and class meeting.

Strengths: Professor Campbell is a very supportive, knowledgeable, and clear instructor. She allows us to lead the discussion to topics that we are interested in and always offers interesting insights to enhance our discussion. The literature that we read is very diverse -- it spans multiple centuries, continents, and genres. This diversity is one of the best parts of the class because each week's reading would always bring something new. My classmates are another strength. Everyone was very engaged and contributed ideas that I had not considered before. Overall, a fantastic course with interesting material and even more interesting discussions!

Weaknesses: None!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Any small discussion section is impacted by online learning, but I felt like our course responded well to the limitations. I think break-out rooms were always a great time to discuss as small groups. I especially appreciated our bi-weekly, informal check-ins at the start of class to see how us as a class was doing outside of our work. Anytime we had other media to share was a nice touch.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this to a student who has not had much engagement with transatlantic literature. For someone who has, this course might not feel incredibly engaging or challenging.

Yes -- this class has a deep and complex reading list, Prof. Campbell gives amazing feedback and cares about her students' wellbeing, and the assignments encourage meaningful writing. If you are interested in the Black Atlantic at all, English major or not, consider taking this class!

Yes, I would recommend this course to others, especially those interested in social justice, history, and older literature. I learned so much about the origins of racist thought in the West and about non-Western systems of gender. I also was able to read some interesting texts that I had no prior exposure to, such as The Woman of Colour.

Yes of course!! Professor Campbell is absolutely fantastic. She is so sweet, supportive, and helpful in improving my writing. She provides very detailed feedback on every essay and gives opportunities for revision, which I really appreciate. The course itself is also so interesting. It covers a ton of authors who are not typically introduced in the core classes. Taking this course greatly expanded my knowledge of English literature and made me more aware of non-white, non-male authors and their brilliant publications. A must-take for all English majors!

Absolutely yes!  The material is interesting and full of pieces that are not often included in long 18th century literature, and you will gain or maintain experience in discussing race, gender, and many other themes in depth. Prof Campbell is also wonderful, cares a lot about her students, and gives very helpful feedback on writing.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
